content.description: Pretty much the best 5.11 at the Pool Wall. Steep, balancey, juggy and a no hands rest just before clipping the anchors, right at the steepest part of the wall. Don't be put off by all the glue!
content.protection: Draws, there are typically 'biners at the chains.
content.location: Just right of the Alcove area, find a nice flat "peninsula" right at the base, rope up and climb.

content.description:
This is a bouldery little route to the left of

Ze Boom Boom Room

. It starts off with a tricky little boulder problem that ends around the 4th bolt. Then it is 5.11 climbing (that is a little contrived) to the top. The original first bolt went away with the massive flake it was drilled into. It would be a good idea to stick clip the first bolt (previously the 2nd).
content.location:
This is on the far right side of Alcove, one route to the left of

Ze Boom Boom Room

.

climbs.name: Tropical Depression
climbs.fa: Garrett Reigan Eric Wright, Ariel Wiertenberger

content.description:
This is one of the driest route in Ouray, certainly for the grade. It's a squeeze job in between our other route to the right, Dirty Rotten Scoundrel and the outstanding

Ze Boom Boom Room

to the left. When everything else is dripping wet, this one is often dry, and it faces south, so it dries quickly if it's been pouring out.  Further, unlike some other steeper routes in the alcove that also might be dryish, the anchors on this climb do not become wet before the rest of the route. So, if it's raining out, don't despair.
content.protection:
It has its own starting bolt. Then it shares two bolts on the climb to the right. Then it has its own nasty, left handed throw to a friendly hold. Tall, skinny people will love this. Also, people that like to climb even when everyone else is whining about the rainy weather will love this. The bolts are stainless steel Fixe 3/8" 3.5 inch.

There is a three bolt anchor at the top. The chains are too skinny as of August 2013 and will get up graded.
content.location: This route is in the Alcove area on the Pool Wall in Ouray.

content.description: This route is listed as "unknown 5.8" on the main page for the Pool Wall. It's a fairly short route but has good sustained difficulty the whole way. The crux is perhaps between the first and second bolt before mellowing out a bit toward the top.
content.protection: 3 bolts to a two bolt anchor with chains. The chains form a pretty extreme angle when set up for rappelling down, and extending them would put less strain on the bolts.
content.location:
It is in between

Keep On Keepin' On

and

Corner Pocket

on the right side looking up the rocky gully.

content.description: Climb up the slab with moves that look harder than they are.  Pass one short steep section to the first two bolt anchor. If you want, continue up the slab to a good stance.  Then one final mantle to the left brings you to a large ledge with a second two bolt anchor.
content.protection: Bolts: 4 to the first anchor, 3 more to a second anchor.
content.location:
This route is one of several nice routes in the alcove area of the Pool Wall in Ouray, a friendly place to climb with closely spaced bolts. Park in the upper lot for the pool in town. Cross the road and head up the obvious wash. You pass an old no trespassing sign, access is currently allowed, continue up the wash and you will be in the alcove

Test Drive is the fifth route from the left in the alcove, two routes right of

Groove Tube

.  It starts up a slab to a two bolt anchor, and an extension continues up to a large ledge.

content.description:
If you already lead

Test Drive

to the top, the guidebook says you can also toprope the right face (the book calls this a 10 variation, but offers no more information). The face can be dusty/crumbly in places, and there is not really a defined route (yet), but there are some interesting moves, and it is a totally different route from the standard, excepting the final mantel, which both share.
content.location:
From

Test Drive

, swing your rope around to the right. It lays perfectly straight down the dusty face.

content.description: This route was put up recently by Eric Wright with stainless steel bolts and hangers, so it'll be the shiny ones whereas the older routes will be rusty (from being in line with the waterfall).  The first half is slick while the upper section is fun edges and friction.  Note: the stainless steel bolts and 3-bolt anchor are a welcome addition to this area but of course more expensive.  Help him out if you meet him out there!
content.protection:
9 bolts to a 3-bolt anchor.  Anchor is not visible from the ground, but is approximately the same level (a little lower) than

Groove Tube

and just on the left side of the waterfall notch.
content.location:
This is located in the Alcove area of the Ouray Pool area.  This is now the 2nd route from the left, just left of (about 3 feet)

Groove is in the Heart

and just right of the 11.  In fact, the lower section can be climbed by clipping bolts on the 11 as well.

content.description: Climb up past a few good slabby sections to the top.
content.location:
This is located right of

Groove Tube

, left of

Test Drive

.

content.description: This route is still pretty dirty, so watch for small rocks as you ascend. Overall, It is a nice and easy route with a well-protected crux just before you top out.
content.protection: 5 bolts to an anchor with chains parallel to each other vertically. Bring a full anchor or alpine draw to account for this offset.
content.location: This route is at the mouth of The Alcove.

content.description: Mullet Days is dirty, awkward, but hey, if you're breaking into the grade, you can set a TR and grumble about this one.... If, however, more people ignore this description and clean this bad boy up, maybe it becomes palatable?
content.location:
It is to the right of

Lunch Bucket and Romper Room

, the two that share anchors, down from the three shorties and two really short 5.5s.

content.description: Climb up the slightly overhanging face into a corner.  Then move right onto the arete and jug haul to the top.  Balancy, short, and fun.
content.location:
This is located downhill of

Center Pocket

.  There are three bolt lines on a slightly overhanging, brown face that stop at the first ledge.  No Se is the leftmost of them.  The middle of the three shares anchors with No Se.

content.description:
Climb through a low roof/scoop via odd stems and compression moves.  This route was given the name "Romper Room."  But when I bolted in 2003-2004, I called it "Lunch Bucket."  It shares the same chains with "

No-Se

."
content.location:
This is the line right of "

No-Se

" located in the Alcove.

content.description: Climb up the wall on pockets and edges. Getting started is the crux.
content.location:
This route is one of several nice routes in the alcove area of the Pool Wall in Ouray, a friendly place to climb with closely spaced bolts. Park in the upper lot for the pool in town. Cross the road and head up the obvious wash. You pass an old no trespassing sign, access is currently allowed, continue up the wash and you will be in the alcove.

Keep On Keepin' On is on the right when hiking up the obvious scree filled wash that leads past the alcove.  It is the furthest route uphill on the right wall.

content.description: This is one of the better 'easy' routes in the alcove. Scramble up the loose slope at the left border of the alcove to get to the start. Follow 11 bolts to an anchor. There is a second pitch.
content.protection: 11 bolts to a two bolt anchor with chains.
content.location: It is the leftmost route in the alcove.

content.description: Climb up the longer water groove on the left wall.  This has fun moves with good stemming.  It is longer than most of the routes in the alcove. Fun.
content.location:
This route is one of several nice routes in the alcove area of the pool wall in Ouray. A friendly place to climb with closly spaced bolts.  Park in the upper lot for the pool in town.  Cross the road and head up the obvious wash.  You pass an old no trespassing sign, access is currently allowed, continue up the wash and you will be in the alcove.

Groove is in the Heart

is the third route on the left after entering the alcove.

content.description: This route is listed as Burger 5.8, I've also heard it called Grilled Cheese. In reality, it is a very easy 5.5, well-protected, and makes a good introductory lead.
content.protection: 4 bolts to a two bolt anchor with chains.
content.location:
This is to the right of

First Time Out

. Both of these route make good first leads for the novice sport climber.

content.description: The crux is moving past the last bolt to the anchors.  It is fun and short.
content.protection: Three bolts to the anchor.  When I did the route, the top bolt was bent from rock fall but was still clipable.
content.location:
This route is one of several nice routes in the alcove area of the pool wall in Ouray.  It is a friendly place to climb with closely spaced bolts. Park in the upper lot for the pool in town.  Cross the road and head up the obvious wash.  You pass an old no trespassing sign, access is currently allowed, continue up the wash and you will be in the alcove.

Groove Is In The Heart is the second route from the left once you enter the alcove.  The top half climbs a water groove.

content.description: This is a short but enjoyable route.  This would be a really good starting lead as it is closely bolted and is of an easy grade.
content.location:
This route is one of several nice routes in the alcove area of the pool wall in Ouray. A friendly place to climb with closely spaced bolts. Park in the upper lot for the pool in town. Cross the road and head up the obvious wash. You pass an old no trespassing sign, access is currently allowed, continue up the wash and you will be in the alcove

First Time Out is right of

Test Drive

.  It is on the left wall just as you begin heading up the obvious, scree-filled wash.

content.description:
This a left-leaning, shallow, dihedral ramp. You can do this route in so many different ways. You can stem or face climb to the left of the seam. Half the route is rotten and chossy.

The extension above first anchor is 11c; take an orange TCU for the big hueco moving off the ledge. The lower section stays dry in the rain.
content.location:
It is to the right of

Ze Boom Boom Room

. It's obvious.

content.description: This route has some sustained difficult climbing right off the ground. Start at a right-angling crack, laybacking your way up. The main crux is at the second clip. Pull through the roof with some good holds out left. The technical face climbing is sustained until the 8th clip, and you are home free after that. Rockfall is a possibility, so wear your helmets; however, if you stay in the dark streaked rock, none of the holds you need should peel.
content.location:
It is the leftmost route in the alcove, just around the corner from

Guiding Light

.

content.description: Climb up moves utilizing some pockets. It is short.
content.location:
This route is one of several nice routes in the alcove area of the pool wall in Ouray. It is a friendly place to climb with closely spaced bolts. Park in the upper lot for the pool in town. Cross the road and head up the obvious wash. You pass an old no trespassing sign, access is currently allowed, continue up the wash and you will be in the alcove.

California Stars is just right of

Keep On Keepin' On

on the right wall of the scree filled wash.

content.description:
As the name suggests, this is a great climb until you reach her FACE. Slabby, washed out rock makes for interesting holds as the rock is incredibly smooth from weathering. Then, about 15 feet below the top the real fun begins....

Because this climb wasn't on MP, I accidentally climbed it to set up toprope for the girlfriend thinking it was a 5.9+.
content.protection: There are 2 chains at the top, and it is well-protected with a fair amount of bolts.
content.location:
This is to the left of the

Groove Tube

and the shorter

5.10c climb

.

climbs.name: Bell Curve A.K.A. Silent But Deadly

content.description: Climb straight up the steep pillar via side pulls pinches, slaps (powerful) to an eventual crimp that aids in gaining a nice rest ledge just under a scoop/overhang.  Next move up and left into a small dihedral that leads up and out of the scoop/overhang (technical) until you reach a nice jug.  From here, traverse left via small crimps (start crux-to end) and delicate, hidden foot placements.  This will lead you to a serious of left handed side pulls and lay backs (powerful) to the chains.
content.location: On the far right of the Alcove is a smaller Alcove/hidden nook that host an obvious steep pillar at the bottom. A nice ledge stance under a scoop/overhang at the mid point.  The finish has a very noticeable thin crux face.
